lesson.name: Lesson 1.12: Writing the Equation of a Line

page.title: 1.12.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will continue to examine and create linear models with linear equations relating two variables. You will also look at several ways to write the equation of a line based on the information given.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Write an equation of the line given the slope and \( y \)-intercept.
  • Write an equation of the line given the slope and a point.
  • Write an equation of the line given two points.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 1.12.1: Using the Slope Formula
  • 1.12.2: Writing an Equation Given the Slope and \(y\)-Intercept
  • 1.12.2: Self Check
  • 1.12.3: Writing an Equation Given the Slope and a Point 
  • 1.12.3: Self Check 
  • 1.12.4: Writing an Equation Given Two Points
  • 1.12.4: Self Check
  • 1.12.5: Choosing a Method to Write an Equation

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 1.12.6: Practice
  • 1.12.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 1.12.1: Using the Slope Formula
page.contents:
Warm-Up Activity

Use the slope formula, \( m =\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}\), to find the slope of the line through the given points.

1. \( (1, -2) \) and \( (3, 4) \)

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

\( m= 3 \)

First, name \( (1, −2) \) as point 1 and \( (3, 4) \) as point 2.

\( (x_1, y_1) \) and \( (x_2, y_2) \)

\( (1,−2) \) and \( (3, 4) \)

Use the slope formula.

\( m=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \)

Substitute the values: \( y_2 = 4, y_1 = -2, x_2 = 3, x_1 = 1 \).

\( m=\frac{4-(-2)}{3-(1)} \)

Simplify.

\( m=\frac{6}{2} \)

\( m=3 \)


2. \( (-2, -3) \) and \( (-7, 4) \)

Check your answer:

\( m=-\frac{7}{5} \)

First, name \( (−2, −3) \) as point 1 and \( (−7, 4) \) as point 2.

\( (x_1, y_1) \) and \( (x_2, y_2) \)

\( (−2,−3)\) and \( (−7, 4) \)

Use the slope formula.

\( m=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \)

Substitute the values: \( y_2 = 4, y_1 = −3, x_2 = −7, x_1 = −2 \).

\( m= \frac{4-(-3)}{-7-(-2)} \)

Simplify.

\( m= \frac{7}{-5} \)

\( m= -\frac{7}{5} \)

page.title: 1.12.2: Writing an Equation Given the Slope and y-Intercept
page.contents:
Activity

Recall that the slope-intercept form of the equation of a line is \( y = mx+b \), where \(m\) is the slope and \(b\) is the \( y \)-intercept. The \( y \)-intercept is the point where the graph crosses the \( y \)-axis. For \( y \)-intercept \( b \), the coordinates of the point are \( (0, b) \).

1. For each of the three equations below, tell the slope, \( m \), and \( y \)-intercept, \( b \).

a. \( y=2x +5 \)
b. \( y = -3x + 2 \)
c. \( y=-\frac{1}{5}x-1 \)

a. \( m=2, b = 5 \)
b. \( m = -3, b =2 \)
c. \( m = - \frac{1}{5}, b = -1 \)


2. Here are some slopes and \( y \)-intercepts. Tell which equation matches each set of slopes and \( y \)-intercepts.

a. slope: \( -2 \), \( y \)-intercept: \( 3 \)
b. slope: \( 3 \), \( y \)-intercept: \( -2 \)
c. slope: \( 2 \), \( y \)-intercept: \( -3 \)
d. slope: \(\frac{1}{2}\), \( y \)-intercept: \( -3 \)

Equations: 
\( y = 2x - 3 \)
\( y = -2x +3 \)
\( y = \frac{1}{2}x - 3 \)
\( y = 3x - 2 \)

a. \( y = -2x +3 \)
b. \( y = 3x - 2 \)
c. \( y = 2x - 3 \)
d. \( y = \frac{1}{2}x - 3 \)


The \( y \)-intercept is the point where the graph crosses the \(y\)-axis. For \( y \)-intercept \( b \), the coordinates of the point are \( (0, b) \). 

3. Write the equation of a line with the following slope and \( y \)-intercept in slope-intercept form.

a. slope \( −9 \) and \( y \)-intercept \( (0, −4) \)

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

\( y = −9x − 4 \)

First, name the slope.
\( m = −9 \)

Then, name the \( y \)-intercept.
\( y \)-intercept \( (0, −4) \)

Write the slope-intercept form of the equation of a line.
\( y = mx + b \)

Substitute the values into \( y = mx + b \).
\( y = −9x + (−4) \)

Write the equation.
\(y = −9x − 4 \)


b. slope \( \frac{2}{5} \) and \( y \)-intercept \( (0, 4) \)  

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

\( y = \frac{2}{5}x + 4 \)

First, name the slope.
\( m = \frac{2}{5} \)

Then, name the \( y \)-intercept.
\( y \)-intercept \( (0, 4) \)

Write the slope-intercept form of the equation of a line.
\( y = mx + b \)

Substitute the values into \( y = mx + b \).
\( y = \frac{2}{5}x + 4 \)

Write the equation.
\( y = \frac{2}{5}x + 4 \)

page.title: 1.12.2: Self Check
page.contents: Write the equation of a line in slope-intercept form with a slope of \( \frac{3}{4} \) and a \( y \)-intercept of \( -2 \).

answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The slope intercept form is \( y=mx+b \). The slope is \( m= -\frac{3}{4} \) and the \(y\)-intercept is \( b=-2 \), so this is the correct equation.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The slope-intercept form of the equation of a line is \( y=mx+b \). Be careful with the signs during substitution. The answer is \( y = - \frac{3}{4} x - 2 \).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Make sure to use the correct form. This is standard form, not slope-intercept form. The answer is \( y = - \frac{3}{4} x - 2 \).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The slope-intercept form of the equation of a line is \( y=mx+b \). Be careful with the signs during substitution. The answer is \( y = - \frac{3}{4} x - 2 \).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 1.12.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Write Equations Given a Slope and \( y \)-Intercept

We can determine the slope and intercept of a line if the equation is written in slope-intercept form, \( y=mx+b \). Now we will do the reverse—we will start with the slope and \( y \)-intercept and use them to find the equation of the line.

Example: 

Find the equation of a line with slope \( −1 \) and \( y \)-intercept \( (0,−3) \).

Solution: 

Name the slope.

\( m = -1 \)

Name the \( y \)-intercept.

\( b = -3 \)

Substitute the values into \( y = mx + b \).

\( y = -1x + -3 \) 
\( y = -x-3 \)


The same information can be picked up from a graph of a line. 

Example: 

Find the equation of the line shown in the graph.

 Solution:

Find the slope by counting the rise and run.

\( m=\frac{rise}{run} \) 

From \( (0, -4) \) to \( (3,-2) \) the slope is \

\(m = \frac{2}{3} \).

Find the \( y \)-intercept.

\( y \)-intercept \( (0, -4) \)
\( b = -4 \)

Substitute the values into \( y = mx + b \).

\( y = mx +b \)
\( y = \frac{2}{3} x - 4 \)

Try It: Write Equations Given a Slope and \( y \)-Intercept

Write the equation of the line graphed below in slope-intercept form:


Write down your answer, and then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to write the equation of the line in slope-intercept form:

Find the slope by counting the rise and run.

\( m=\frac{rise}{run} \) 
From \( (0, 1) \) to \( (5, 4) \) the slope is \( m = \frac{4}{5} \).

Find the \( y \)-intercept.

\( y \)-intercept \( (0, 1) \)
\( b = 1 \)

Substitute the values into \( y = mx + b\).

\( y = mx +b \)
\( y = \frac{3}{5} x + 1 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.12.3: Writing an Equation Given the Slope and a Point
page.contents:
Activity

What if the point you are given isn’t a \( y \)-intercept? Point-slope is a great form to use when you are given the slope and any point. 

First, work to derive the point-slope formula by completing the following steps:

Start with the slope formula as \( m= \frac{y-y_1}{x-x_1} \).

Step 1: Multiply both sides of the equation by \( x - x_1 \).

Check your answer: \( m(x-x_1)=\left(\frac{y-y_1}{x-x_1}\right)(x-x_1) \)


Step 2: Simplify.

Check your answer: \( m(x-x_1)=y-y_1 \)


Step 3: Rewrite the equation with the \(y\) terms on the left.

Check your answer: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \)


With your partner, you will find the equation of the line in point-slope form that goes through the point \( (3, 4) \) and has a slope of 2 by answering the following questions.

1. Use the point and slope to graph the line on a coordinate plane using a graphing calculator or Desmos.

Write down your answer, and then select the Solution button to check your work.

Sample answer:


2. Write the point-slope form.

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

\( y-y_1=m(x-x_1) \)


3. Name the point \( (x_1, y_1) \) and the slope, \( m \).

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

\( x_1=3,\ y_1=4,\ m =2 \)


4. Substitute the point and slope into the point-slope form.

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

\( y -4 =2(x-3) \)


5. Now, with your partner, each solve for \(y\) to write the equation in slope-intercept form. Compare your answers for any possible errors. Come to an agreement on your equation.

Check your answer:

\( y = 2x - 2 \)

page.title: 1.12.4: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Find an Equation of the Line Given Two Points

So far, you have two options for finding an equation of a line: slope-intercept or point-slope. When you start with two points, it makes more sense to use the point-slope form.

But then you need the slope. You can find the slope with just two points and then use it and one of the given points to find the equation.

For example: 

Write the equation of a line that contains the points \( (-3, -1) \) and \( (2, -2) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

Step 1: Find the slope using the given points.

Find the slope of the line through \( (-3, -1) \) and \( (2, -2) \).

\( m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 -x_1} \) 
\( m = \frac{-2 - (-1)}{2-(-3)} \) 
\( m = \frac{-1}{5} \)
\( m = - \frac{1}{5} \)

Step 2: Choose one point.

Choose either point.

\( (x_1, y_1) \)
\( (2, -2) \)

Step 3: Substitute the values into the point-slope form, \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify.

\( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \)
\( y - (-2) = \frac{1}{5}(x - 2) \)
\( y + 2 = \frac{1}{5}x + \frac{2}{5} \)

Step 4: Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

  

\( y = \frac{1}{5}x - \frac{8}{5} \)


Use this table for easy reference to find an equation of a line given two points.

Step 1 

Find the slope using the given points. 
\( m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 -x_1} \) 

Step 2

Choose one point.

Step 3

Substitute the values into the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \).

Step 4

Write the equation in slope-intercept form.


To find an equation of a line given the slope and a point, follow these steps:

Step 1

Identify the slope.

Step 2

Identify the point.

Step 3

Substitute the values into the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x -x_1) \).

Step 4

Write the equation in slope-intercept form.


Try It: Writing the Equation of a Line Given Two Points

Write the equation of a line that contains the points \( (-3, 5) \) and \( (-3, 4) \).

Write down your answer, and then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to find an equation of a line that contains the points \( (-3, 5) \) and \( (-3, 4) \).
Again, the first step will be to find the slope.

1. Find the slope of the line through \( (-3, 5) \) and \( (-3, 4) \).

2. \( m = \frac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 -x_1} \) 

3. \( m = \frac{4-5}{-3-(-3)} \) 

4. \( m = \frac{-1}{0} \)

A line with undefined slope is a vertical line. Both given points have an \( x \)-coordinate of \( -3 \). So, the equation of the line is \( x = -3 \). There is no \( y \), so the equation cannot be written in slope-intercept form.


How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.12.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Write the Equation of a Line Given the Slope and a Point

Writing an equation using the slope-intercept form works well when you are given the slope and \(y\)-intercept. If you are given the slope and another point that is not the \(y\)-intercept, we need another form of the equation of a line. 

The point-slope form of an equation of a line can be derived from the formula for slope. Suppose you have a line that has slope \(m\) and that contains some specific point \( (x_1, y_1) \) as point 1 and some other point, \( (x, y) \), as point 2. You can write the slope of this line and then change it to a different form.

The point-slope form of an equation of a line with slope \(m\) and containing the point \( (x_1, y_1) \) is: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). You can use this form to find the equation of a line when you are given the slope and a point.

Example 1 

Write the equation of a line with slope \( m = \frac{1}{3} \) that contains the point \( (6, -4) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form. 

Step 1: Identify the slope. 
The slope is given.

\( m = \frac{1}{3} \)

Step 2: Identify the point.
The point is given.

\( (x_1, y_1) \)
\( (6, -4) \)

Step 3: Substitute the values into the point-slope form, \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). Simplify.

\( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \)
\( y - (-4) = \frac{1}{3}(x - 6) \)
\( y + 4 = \frac{1}{3}x + 2 \)

Step 4: Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

\( y = \frac{1}{3}x -2 \)


To find an equation of a line given the slope and a point, follow these steps:

Step 1:

Identify the slope.

Step 2:

Identify the point.

Step 3:

Substitute the values into the point-slope form, \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \).

Step 4:

Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

Example 2 

Find the equation of a horizontal line that contains the point \((-2, -6)\). Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

Step 1: Identify the slope. Every horizontal line has slope 0.

\(m = 0 \)

Step 2: Identify the point.

\( (x_1, y_1) \)
\( (-2, -6) \)

Step 3: Substitute the values into the point-slope form, \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). Simplify.

\( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \)
\( y - (-6) = 0(x - (-2)) \)
\( y + 6 = 0 \)

Step 4: Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

\( y = -6 \)
\( y = 0x - 6 \)


Try It: Writing the Equation of a Line Given the Slope and Point

Write the equation of a line with slope \( m = -\frac{2}{5} \) that contains the point \( (10, -5) \). Write the equation in slope-intercept form. 

Write down your answer, and then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to write the equation of a line with a point and slope using a general strategy.

Step 1: Identify the slope.

\( m = -\frac{2}{5}\) 

Step 2: Identify the point.

\( (x_1, y_1) \)
\( (10, -5) \)

Step 3: Substitute the values into the point-slope form, \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). Simplify.

\( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \)
\( y - (-5) = (x - 10) \)
\( y + 5 = x + 4 \)

Step 4: Write the equation in slope-intercept form.

\( y = x - 1 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.12.4: Writing an Equation Given Two Points
page.contents:
Activity

Answer the following questions.

1. Use the graph below to pick two points and find the slope between the two points.


Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

The slope of the line is \( - \frac{1}{3} \).


2. Use your two points in the slope formula to confirm the slope is correct.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Sample Answer: \( m=\frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1}=\frac{1-3}{4-(-2)}=\frac{-2}{6}=-\frac{1}{3} \)


3. Using the slope and a point, write your equation in point-slope form.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Sample Answer:

\( m = - \frac{1}{3} \) and \( (4, 1) \)

\( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \) becomes: \( y - 1 = - \frac{1}{3}(x - 4) \).


4. Now write your equation in slope-intercept form.

Enter your answer here:

Check your answer:

\( y =- \frac{1-3} x + \frac{7}{3} \)


5. Look at your equation and the original graph. What do you notice? How can you use a graph to check your equation?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The \( y \)-intercept of the graph is \( \frac{7}{3} \) and the slope is \( -\frac{1}{3} \).

page.title: 1.12.3: Self Check
page.contents: Which equation represents the slope-intercept form of the equation of a line with slope \( m = -\frac{3}{4} \) that contains the point \( (4, −7) \)?

answer.response:
That’s correct! Check yourself:
Substitute \(-\frac{3}{4} \) for \( m, 4 \) for \( x_1 \), and \( −7 \) for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \).
Simplify the equation \( y - (-7) = -\frac{3}{4}(x - 4) \) to get \( y + 7 = -\frac{3}{4}x + 3 \).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Remember the \( x \)-coordinate is the first coordinate and the \( y \)-coordinate is the second coordinate. 

Substitute \(-\frac{3}{4} \) for \( m, 4 \) for \( x_1 \), and \( -7 \) for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \).
Simplify the equation \( y - (-7) = -\frac{3}{4}(x - 4) \) to get \( y + 7 = -\frac{3}{4}x + 3 \).
The answer is \( y = -\frac{3}{4}x - 4 \).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way:
Substitute \(-\frac{3}{4} \) for \( m, 4 \) for \( x_1 \), and \( -7 \) for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \).
Simplify the equation \( y - (-7) = -\frac{3}{4}(x - 4) \).
Be careful when using the Distributive Property to multiply \( -\frac{3}{4} \) by \( x \) and by \( 4 \).
The equation simplifies to \( y + 7 = -\frac{3}{4}x + 3 \).
The answer is \( y =-\frac{3}{4}x - 4 \).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way:
Substitute \(-\frac{3}{4} \) for \( m, 4 \) for \( x_1 \), and \( -7 \) for \( y_1 \) in the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \).
Simplify the equation \( y - (-7) = -\frac{3}{4}(x - 4) \). Watch the signs when simplifying. The equation simplifies to \( y + 7 = -\frac{3}{4}x + 3 \).
The answer is \( y =-\frac{3}{4}x- 4 \).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 1.12.4: Self Check
page.contents: Which equation represents the slope-intercept form of the equation of a line containing the points \( (-2, -4) \) and \( (1, -3) \)?

answer.response:
That’s correct! Check yourself:
First find the slope by substituting \( -3 \) for \( y_2 \), \( -4 \) for \( y_1 \), 1 for \( x_2 \), and \( -2 \) for \( x_1 \) in the slope formula: \( m= \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \). The slope is \( m= \frac{-3-(-4)}{1-(-2)} = \frac{1}{3} \). 
Substitute the slope and the coordinates of the points into the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \).
Simplify the equation \( y - (-3) = \frac{1}{3}(x - 1) \) to get \( y + 3 = \frac{1}{3}x - \frac{1}{3} \).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: 

First find the slope by substituting \( -3 \) for \( y_2 \), \( -4 \) for \( y_1 \), 1 for \( x_2 \), and \( -2 \) for \( x_1 \) in the slope formula: \( m= \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \). The slope is \( m= \frac{-3-(-4)}{1-(-2)} = \frac{1}{3} \). 

Substitute the slope and the coordinates of the points into the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). You can use the coordinates from either point. Make sure you choose the \( x \)- and \( y \)-value from the same point. 

Simplify the equation \( y - (-3) = \frac{1}{3}(x - 1) \) to get \( y + 3 = \frac{1}{3}x - \frac{1}{3} \). The answer is \( y =\frac{1}{3}x - 3\frac{1}{3} \).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way:  

First find the slope by substituting \( -3 \) for \( y_2 \), \( -4 \) for \( y_1 \), 1 for \( x_2 \), and \( -2 \) for \( x_1 \) in the slope formula: \( m= \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \). The slope is \( m= \frac{-3-(-4)}{1-(-2)} = \frac{1}{3} \). 

Substitute the slope and the coordinates of the points into the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - (-3) = \frac{1}{3}(x - 1) \) to get \( y + 3 = \frac{1}{3}x - \frac{1}{3} \). The answer is \( y =\frac{1}{3}x - 3\frac{1}{3} \).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: 

Remember, the \(x\)-coordinate is the first coordinate and the \(y\)-coordinate is the second coordinate. 

The slope is the change in \(y\) over the change in \(x\). Find the slope by substituting \( -3 \) for \( y_2 \), \( -4 \) for \( y_1 \), 1 for \( x_2 \), and \( -2 \) for \( x_1 \) in the slope formula: \( m= \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \). The slope is \( m= \frac{-3-(-4)}{1-(-2)} = \frac{1}{3} \). 

Substitute the slope and the coordinates of the points into the point-slope form: \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \). 

Simplify the equation \( y - (-3) = \frac{1}{3}(x - 1) \) to get \( y + 3 = \frac{1}{3}x - \frac{1}{3} \). The answer is \( y =\frac{1}{3}x - 3\frac{1}{3} \).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 1.12.5: Choosing a Method to Write an Equation
page.contents:
Cool-Down Activity

You have seen that you can use either the slope-intercept form or the point-slope form to find an equation of a line. Which form you use will depend on the information you are given.

The table can be used as a reference.

To Write an Equation of a Line

If given:

Use:

Form:

Slope and \( y\)-intercept

slope-intercept

\( y = mx + b \)

Slope and a point

point-slope

\( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \)

Two points

point-slope

\( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \)

1. Each partner should find a slip labeled “Points.” Place the remaining Equation slips in a pile face down to be used in the second step.

Find the slope of the line containing the points on your slip.
Enter your answer here:

Answers will vary, but you will use the point-slope form to find the line \( y - y_1 = m(x - x_1) \) given the two points on your slip.

Take turns sharing with your partner the slope of your line and the method used to find the slope.

2. Partners take turns choosing Equation slips from the pile to see if the equation represents a line formed by the points on their Points slip. 

  • One partner chooses an Equation slip from the pile. Decide if the equation represents a line through the points on your Points slip. If it does, explain to your partner how you know. Keep the slip. If it does not represent a line through your points, give the Equation slip to your partner.
  • Your partner should verify the equation represents a line through the points on your partner’s Points slip. Discuss and reach an agreement. If the equation does not represent a line through either partner’s points, set it aside. 
  • Take turns choosing Equation slips until they are all gone. (There are 6 Equation slips.) Each partner should end with a total of 2 Equation slips that match. There will be 2 Equations slips that do not match either set of points.
  • Which equations represent a line through your points?

Enter your answer here:

Answers may vary. Compare your answer to the samples.

Solution: Points: \( (3, 4) \) and \( (6, 2) \): \( y - 2 = -12(x - 6) \); \( y - 4 = -12(x - 3) \)

Points: \( (-3, -4) \) and \( (6, 2) \): \( y - 2 = 23(x - 6) \); \( y + 4 = 23(x + 3) \)

Equations with no match: \( y + 4 = -12(x + 3) \) and \( y - 4 = 23(x - 3) \)


3. Is identifying the slope enough to match your set of points to an equation?
Enter your answer here:

Sample response: No, the slope is not enough to identify the equation because lines with the same slope can go through different points.

page.title: 1.12.6: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

In questions 1-2, choose the equation of a line with the given slope and y-intercept that best represents the line in slope-intercept form .

1. slope 3 and y-intercept (0,5)

Correct! y=3x+5

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.12.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is y=3x+5. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


2. slope −3 and y-intercept (0,−1)

Correct! y=-3x-1

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.12.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is y=-3x-1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


In questions 3-4 choose the slope-intercept form of the equation of the line, shown in each graph.

3.

Correct! \(y=3x-5\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.12.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is y=3x-5. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


4.

Correct! \(y=-2x+4\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.12.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is y=-2x+4. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


5. Choose the equation of a line with the given slope and containing the given point that best represents the line in slope-intercept form.
m=−7, point (−1,−3)

Correct! \(y=-7x-10\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.12.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(y=-7x-10\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


6. Choose the equation of a line containing the given points that best represents the line in slope-intercept form.

Correct! \(y=-\frac72x+4\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.12.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(y=-\frac72x+4\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


7. Choose the equation of a line containing the given points that best represents the line in slope-intercept form.
(3,−4) and (5,−4)

Correct! \(y=-4\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.12.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(y=-4\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 1.12.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Write an equation of the line given the slope and \(y\)-intercept.
  • Write an equation of the line given the slope and a point.
  • Write an equation of the line given two points.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 1.12.1: Using the Slope Formula
    • In this activity, you reviewed using the slope formula to find the slope between two points.
  • 1.12.2: Writing an Equation Given the Slope and \(y\)-Intercept
    • In this activity, you used the given slope and \(y\)-intercept to write the equation of a line in slope-intercept form. You also worked to find the slope and \(y\)-intercept from a graph to then write the equation of the line in slope-intercept form.
  • 1.12.2: Self Check 
  • 1.12.3: Writing an Equation Given the Slope and a Point 
    • In this activity, you used point-slope form to write the equation of a line given a slope and a point. You then wrote the equation in slope-intercept form.
  • 1.12.3: Self Check 
  • 1.12.4: Write an Equation Given Two Points
    • In this activity, you found the slope between two points and confirmed it with the slope formula. You then used one point and the slope to write the equation of a line in point-slope form. From here, you wrote the equation in slope-intercept form and used the graph to check your equation.
  • 1.12.4: Self Check 
  • 1.12.5: Choosing a Method to Write an Equation
    • In this activity, you discussed when to use each method of writing an equation. With a partner, you worked to find slopes and equations of lines using different methods.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

1.12.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
